titleStmt.title: NFE: Controlled vocabulary for all people

publicationStmt.p: Data from this authority file for people can be reused under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 licence (CC-BY-SA 4.0).

sourceDesc.p: This is the authority file for people used in the "Notes from Egypt" project (https://notesfromegypt.info).

person.name: Dr. Henry Abbott
person.note: Dr. Henry Abbott (1812-1859) was a British physician and amateur collector of Egyptian antiquities who practiced in Cairo. During his residence in Egypt between 1832 and 1852, Dr. Abbott began to accompany archaeologists and explorers on digs and actively participate in excavations throughout the country. The famous Abbott papyrus was named after him.

person.name: Abdallah Pasha
person.note: Abdullah Pasha ibn Ali (commonly referred to simply as Abdullah Pasha; 1801â€“?) was the Ottoman governor (wali) of Sidon Eyalet between May 1820 and May 1832, with a nine-month interruption in 1822â€“23. Like his predecessors Jazzar Pasha and Sulayman Pasha, Abdullah Pasha ruled from the port city of Acre. During his reign, all of Palestine and the Syrian coastline came under his jurisdiction. Among his major military victories was his survival of an imperial-backed siege of Acre in 1822 instigated by the Farhi family in retaliation for Abdullah's execution of his mentor Haim Farhi, the suppression of revolts in Mount Lebanon and Jerusalem in 1824 and 1826, respectively, and the 1831 capture of the Sanur fortress. While Abdullah oversaw a period of relative stability in Syria, during his reign the region also experienced economic reversals and increasing poverty, while Acre's key role as an export center of Levantine cotton and olive oil increasingly diminished. Abdullah was the last governor of Sidon to rule from Acre and his defeat to the forces of Muhammad Ali of Egypt in 1832 marked the end of Acre as a political and economic power. Following his defeat, he lived in exile in Egypt and then the Hejaz, where he died.

person.name: Abraham
person.note: Abraham (originally Abram) is the common patriarch of the Abrahamic religions, including Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. In Judaism, he is the founding father of the covenant of the pieces, the special relationship between the Hebrews and God; in Christianity, he is the spiritual progenitor of all believers, Jewish or Gentile; and in Islam he is seen as a link in the chain of prophets that begins with Adam and culminates in Muhammad.

person.name: Achmet
person.note: One of the crew of Lucie Duff Gordons boat, the cook for the crew

person.name: Sir Alexander Cornewall Duff-Gordon
person.note: Sir Alexander Cornewall Duff-Gordon, 3rd Baronet (3 February 1811 â€“ 27 October 1872) was a British civil servant and Baronet of Halkin. He was the husband of Lucie, Lady Duff-Gordon, the English writer on Egypt.

person.name: Sarah Austin
person.note: Sarah Austin (1793â€“1867), mother of Lucie Duff Gordon, was an English editor, linguist and translator from German

person.name: Amun Ra
person.note: Amun (US: /ËˆÉ‘ËmÉ™n/; also Amon, Ammon, Amen, Ancient Egyptian: jmn, reconstructed [jaËˆmaËnuw]; Greek á¼ŒÎ¼Î¼Ï‰Î½ ÃmmÅn, á¼Î¼Î¼Ï‰Î½ HÃ¡mmÅn) was a major ancient Egyptian deity who appears as a member of the Hermopolitan Ogdoad. Amun was attested from the Old Kingdom together with his wife Amaunet. With the 11th Dynasty (c. 21st century BC), Amun rose to the position of patron deity of Thebes by replacing Montu. After the rebellion of Thebes against the Hyksos and with the rule of Ahmose I (16th century BC), Amun acquired national importance, expressed in his fusion with the Sun god, Ra, as Amun-Ra or Amun-Re.

person.name: Andrasool
person.note: Crew member of Lucie Duff Gordons boat.

person.name: Bacchus/Dionysus
person.note: Dionysus (/daÉª.É™ËˆnaÉªsÉ™s/; Greek: Î”Î¹ÏŒÎ½Ï…ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚) is the god of the grape-harvest, winemaking and wine, of fertility, orchards and fruit, vegetation, insanity, ritual madness, religious ecstasy, festivity and theatre in ancient Greek religion and myth. He is also known as Bacchus (/ËˆbÃ¦kÉ™s/ or /ËˆbÉ‘ËkÉ™s/; Greek: Î’Î¬ÎºÏ‡Î¿Ï‚, BÃ¡kkhos), the name adopted by the Romans; the frenzy he induces is bakkheia.

person.name: Eliza Bromfield
person.note: Sister of William Arnold Bromfeld

person.name: Dante
person.note: Dante Alighieri (Italian: [Ëˆdante aliËˆÉ¡jÉ›Ëri]), probably baptized Durante di Alighiero degli Alighieri and often referred to simply as Dante (/ËˆdÉ‘ËnteÉª, ËˆdÃ¦nteÉª, ËˆdÃ¦nti/, also US: /ËˆdÉ‘Ënti/; c.â€‰1265 â€“ 1321), was an Italian poet, writer and philosopher. His Divine Comedy, originally called ComedÃ¬a (modern Italian: Commedia) and later christened Divina by Giovanni Boccaccio, is widely considered the most important poem of the Middle Ages and the greatest literary work in the Italian language.

person.name: Sir John Gardner Wilkinson
person.note: Sir John Gardner Wilkinson (5 October 1797 â€“ 29 October 1875) was an English traveller, writer and pioneer Egyptologist of the 19th century. He is often referred to as "the Father of British Egyptology".

person.name: Gilbert
person.note: British consul in Alexandria

person.name: Girgis
person.note: A Copt living at Bibbeh

person.name: Hathor
person.note: Hathor (Ancient Egyptian: á¸¥wt-á¸¥r "House of Horus", Greek: á¼‰Î¸ÏÏ HathÅr) was a major goddess in ancient Egyptian religion who played a wide variety of roles. As a sky deity, she was the mother or consort of the sky god Horus and the sun god Ra, both of whom were connected with kingship, and thus she was the symbolic mother of their earthly representatives, the pharaohs. She was one of several goddesses who acted as the Eye of Ra, Ra's feminine counterpart, and in this form she had a vengeful aspect that protected him from his enemies.

person.name: Hekekian Bey
person.note: An Armenian living in Cairo

person.name: Mrs. Hekekian
person.note: wife of Hekekian Bey

person.name: Herodotus
person.note: Herodotus (/hÉªËˆrÉ’dÉ™tÉ™s/; Ancient Greek: á¼©ÏÏŒÎ´Î¿Ï„Î¿Ï‚, HÄ“rÃ³dotos, Attic Greek pronunciation: [hÉ›Ë.rÃ³.do.tos]; c.â€‰484 â€“ c.â€‰425 BC) was an ancient Greek historian who was born in Halicarnassus in the Persian Empire (modern-day Bodrum, Turkey). He is known for having written the book The Histories (Greek: á¼¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎ¯Î±Î¹ HistorÃ­ai), a detailed record of his "inquiry" (á¼±ÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎ¯Î± historÃ­a) on the origins of the Greco-Persian Wars. He is widely considered to have been the first writer to have treated historical subjects using a method of systematic investigationâ€”specifically, by collecting his materials and then critically arranging them into an historiographic narrative. On account of this, he is often referred to as "The Father of History," a title first conferred on him by the first-century BC Roman orator Cicero.

person.name: Hobson
person.note: 19th century traveller in Egypt

person.name: Isis
Janet Ann Ross
person.note: Janet Ann Ross (1842â€“1927), daughter of Lucie Duff Gordon, was an English historian, biographer, and Tuscan cookbook author.

person.name: Juvenal
person.note: Decimus Junius Juvenalis (Latin: [ËˆdÉ›kÉªmÊŠs ËˆjuËnÉª.ÊŠs jÊŠwÉ›ËˆnaËlÉªs]), known in English as Juvenal (/ËˆdÊ’uËvÉ™nÉ™l/ JOO-vÉ™n-É™l), was a Roman poet active in the late first and early second century AD. He is the author of the collection of satirical poems known as the Satires.

person.name: De Leo Bey
person.note: surgeon-in-chief of the Pashaâ€™s troops

person.name: de Lesseps
person.note: Ferdinand Marie, vicomte de Lesseps GCSI (French: [dÉ™ lesÉ›ps]; 19 November 1805 â€“ 7 December 1894) was a French diplomat and later developer of the Suez Canal, which in 1869 joined the Mediterranean and Red Seas, substantially reducing sailing distances and times between Europe and East Asia.

person.name: Maria Malibran
person.note: Maria Felicia Malibran (24 March 1808 â€“ 23 September 1836) was a Spanish singer who commonly sang both contralto and soprano parts, and was one of the best-known opera singers of the 19th century. Malibran was known for her stormy personality and dramatic intensity, becoming a legendary figure after her death at age 28. Contemporary accounts of her voice describe its range, power and flexibility as extraordinary.

person.name: Maurice Duff Gordon
person.note: 4th Duff-Gordon baronet (1849â€“1896), son of Lucie Duff Gordon

person.name: Mehemet Ali
person.note: Muhammad Ali Pasha al-Mas'ud ibn Agha, known as Muhammad Ali of Egypt and the Sudan (Ottoman script: Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„ÛŒ Ù¾Ø§Ø´Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø¹ÙˆØ¯ Ø¨Ù† Ø¢ØºØ§; Arabic: Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø¹Ù„ÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ø´Ø§â€, ALA-LC: Muá¸¥ammad â€˜AlÄ« BÄshÄ; 4 March 1769 â€“ 2 August 1849), was the Albanian Ottoman governor and the de facto ruler of Egypt from 1805 to 1848, is considered the founder of modern Egypt. At the height of his rule, he controlled Lower Egypt, Upper Egypt, Sudan and parts of Arabia and the entire Levant.

person.name: Miriam
person.note: Miriam (×Ö´×¨Ö°×™Ö¸×â€ MÄ«rÉ™yÄm) was described in the Hebrew Bible as the daughter of Amram and Jochebed, and the older sister of Moses and Aaron. She was a prophetess and first appears in the Book of Exodus.

person.name: Muhammad
person.note: Muhammad (Arabic: Ù…ÙØ­ÙÙ…ÙÙ‘Ø¯â€, pronounced [muÄ§ammad]; c. 570 CE â€“ 8 June 632 CE) was an Arab religious, social, and political leader and the founder of Islam. According to Islamic doctrine, he was a prophet, sent to preach and confirm the monotheistic teachings of Adam, Abraham, Moses, Jesus, and other prophets. He is believed to be the final prophet of God in all the main branches of Islam, though some modern denominations diverge from this belief. Muhammad united Arabia into a single Muslim polity, with the Quran as well as his teachings and practices forming the basis of Islamic religious belief.

person.name: Mustapha Aga
person.note: consular agent at Thebes

person.name: Omar Abou el-HalÃ¡weh
person.note: Personal servant of Lady Lucie Duff Gordon during her stay in Egypt

person.name: Osiris
person.note: Osiris (/oÊŠËˆsaÉªrÉªs/, from Egyptian wsjr, Coptic â²Ÿâ²©â²¥â²“â²£â²‰) is the god of fertility, agriculture, the afterlife, the dead, resurrection, life, and vegetation in ancient Egyptian religion. He was classically depicted as a green-skinned deity with a pharaoh's beard, partially mummy-wrapped at the legs, wearing a distinctive atef crown, and holding a symbolic crook and flail.

person.name: Osman
person.note: Member of the crew of Lucie Duff Gordons boat.

person.name: Parker
person.note: General

person.name: Polyphemus
person.note: Polyphemus (/ËŒpÉ’lÉªËˆfiËmÉ™s/; Greek: Î Î¿Î»ÏÏ†Î·Î¼Î¿Ï‚ PolyphÄ“mos Epic Greek: [po.lÃ½.pÊ°É›Ë.mos]; Latin: PolyphÄ“mus Classical Latin: [pÉ”.lÊ²ÊËˆpÊ°eË.mÊŠsÌ ]) is the one-eyed giant son of Poseidon and Thoosa in Greek mythology, one of the Cyclopes described in Homer's Odyssey. His name means "abounding in songs and legends". Polyphemus first appeared as a savage man-eating giant in the ninth book of the Odyssey. In the work of even later authors, however, he is presented as both a successful lover and skilled musician. From the Renaissance on, art and literature reflect all of these interpretations of the giant.

person.name: Prometheus
person.note: In Greek mythology, Prometheus (/prÉ™ËˆmiËÎ¸iÉ™s/; Ancient Greek: Î ÏÎ¿Î¼Î·Î¸ÎµÏÏ‚, [promÉ›ËtÊ°Ã©uÌ¯s], possibly meaning "forethought"), is a Titan god of fire. Prometheus is a culture hero and trickster figure who is credited with the creation of humanity from clay, and who defies the gods by stealing fire and giving it to humanity as civilization. Prometheus is known for his intelligence and for being a champion of humankind, and is also seen as the author of the human arts and sciences generally.

person.name: Prince PÃ¼ckler Muskau
person.note: Prince Hermann Ludwig Heinrich von PÃ¼ckler-Muskau; born as Count PÃ¼ckler, from 1822 Prince; 30 October 1785 â€“ 4 February 1871) was a German nobleman, renowned as an accomplished artist in landscape gardening, as well as the author of a number of books mainly centering around his travels in Europe and Northern Africa, published under the pen name of "Semilasso".

person.name: Rachel
person.note: Rachel (Hebrew: ×¨Ö¸×—Öµ×œâ€, romanized: RÄá¸¥Ãªl, lit. 'ewe') was a Biblical figure, the favorite of Jacob's two wives, and the mother of Joseph and Benjamin, two of the twelve progenitors of the tribes of Israel.

person.name: Ramses II (The Great)
person.note: Ramesses II /ËˆrÃ¦mÉ™siËz, ËˆrÃ¦msiËz, ËˆrÃ¦mziËz/ (variously also spelt Rameses or Ramses, Ancient Egyptian: rêœ¥-ms-sw "Ra is the one who bore him", KoinÄ“ Greek: á¿¬Î±Î¼Î­ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚, romanized: RhamÃ©ssÄ“s, c. 1303 BC â€“ July or August 1213; reigned 1279â€“1213 BC), also known as Ramesses the Great, was the third pharaoh of the Nineteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He is often regarded as the greatest, most celebrated, and most powerful pharaoh of the New Kingdom, itself the most powerful period of Ancient Egypt. He is known as Ozymandias in Greek sources (KoinÄ“ Greek: ÎŸÏƒÏ…Î¼Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚, romanized: OsymandÃ½as), from the first part of Ramesses's regnal name, Usermaatre Setepenre, "The Maat of Ra is powerful, Chosen of Ra".

person.name: Reis
person.note: This refers to the captain of Lucie Duff Gordons ship during her stay in Egypt

person.name: Said Pasha
person.note: Mohamed Sa'id Pasha (Arabic: Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø³Ø¹ÙŠØ¯ Ø¨Ø§Ø´Ø§â€, Turkish: Mehmed Said PaÅŸa, March 17, 1822 â€“ January 17, 1863) was the WÄli of Egypt and Sudan from 1854 until 1863, officially owing fealty to the Ottoman Sultan but in practice exercising virtual independence. He was the fourth son of Muhammad Ali Pasha. Sa'id was a Francophone, educated in Paris. Under Sa'id's rule there were several law, land and tax reforms.

person.name: Shereef
person.note: Crew member of Lucie Duff Gordons boat.

person.name: Sid Achmet el-Berberi
person.note: boat owner from Cairo

person.name: St. George
person.note: Saint George (Greek: Î“ÎµÏÏÎ³Î¹Î¿Ï‚, d. 23 April 303), also George of Lydda, was a Christian who is accepted as a saint in Christianity. In hagiography, as one of the Fourteen Holy Helpers and one of the most prominent military saints, he is immortalized in the legend of Saint George and the Dragon. His memorial, Saint George's Day, is traditionally celebrated on 23 April.

person.name: Tomkins
person.note: 19th century traveller in Egypt

person.name: Wassef
person.note: A copt living at Minieh.

person.name: William Sydney Thayer
person.note: American Consul-General in Egypt during 1861 and 1864.

person.name: Wilkinson
person.note: Consul

person.name: Zankalonee
